body.p: Usually when working with a DITA-based project you can either store the project contents using a Content Management System (CMS) or some open-source version control system like Git or SVN. CMS's usually come with their own translation support so this blog post it mostly for end users who use Git or SVN to store and collaborate on their DITA project.
body.section:
Choosing a Translation Agency
Ideally your translation agency should be able to handle DITA content directly, without you needing to convert the DITA to some intermediary format. This means that you will take full benefit of DITA reuse to minimize translation costs.
As a very important rule, if you plan to translate your project you should get in touch with a DITA-aware translation agency very early in your project's timeline. Reliable translation agencies which translate directly DITA content (for example WHP) usually need to have a preliminary discussion with you about how the project is structured, what terms need to be skipped when translating, how various measuring units are translated, content reuse, taxonomy and handling of screenshots which appear in your DITA content. So the way in which you write your DITA content will be influenced by your discussion with the translation agency.If your translation agency does not directly handle DITA content, there are commercial tools which can be used to convert DITA to XLiff: .

section.title: Optimizing Content for Translation
section.p:
In general there are three main principles to take into account when writing DITA content which will be translated later on:
Use a controlled vocabulary (usually the Simplified Technical English vocabulary).
Avoid reusing inline elements other than product names. This previous DITA Users List discussion should be helpful for you: .
Avoid profiling/filtering content at inline level. For the same reason as (2). You can read more about this in the following article: .

section.title: General DITA Project Structure
section.p: Usually you need to keep a folder containing all your DITA maps/topics in English and have separate folders for other languages containing the equivalent DITA topics translated in that specific language. This article could be an useful read: .

section.title: General Translation Workflow
section.p:
The best case scenario when translating DITA content involves three steps:
You create your content in the primary language using a DITA authoring tool (Oxygen XML Editor).
Before each release you gather all the DITA topics which have been changed and need to be translated. The Oxygen Translation Package Builder plugin might be handy for this.
Send a copy of the relevant DITA files to the translation agency (known also as "localisation service provider").
Receive translated DITA content back from the translation agency and integrate it each language-specific project folder.

This concludes my DITA translation overview. As we do not translate the Oxygen User's Manual in various languages, our internal knowledge of translating DITA content is quite limited so any feedback on this small article would be welcomed.
